text.1:
This surah begins with "Alif Lam Ra". (See its commentary in the first volume under the title "mafatihus suwar".) In Allah SWT's words after Alif Lam Ra, the purpose and objective of the revelation of the Al-Quran to Prophet Muhammad is explained. Allah revealed the Al-Quran to the Messenger of Allah so that the guidance and regulations brought by the Al-Quran could become guidance and direction for his people. With that guidance, they can be brought out of darkness into bright light, or from error and ignorance to the right path and have knowledge and high civilization, so that they obtain the pleasure and love of Allah SWT in this world and the hereafter.

The affirmation of the function of the Al-Quran is very important, especially when connected with the previous verses, where Allah SWT has mentioned the existence of people who deny the Al-Quran, either in part or in its entirety.

Furthermore, in this verse it is explained that the Messenger of Allah can only carry out the task above with the permission and help of Allah SWT, by providing ease and strengthening his determination in facing all obstacles. The Al-Quran is the path laid out by Allah, the Almighty and Most Praiseworthy, for Prophet Muhammad and his people.
text.2:
Allah SWT reminds us again of His power in this verse by affirming that He is the One who possesses and controls everything in the heavens and on earth.

Because Allah SWT is the Owner and Controller of all His creation in this universe, the Qur'an that He revealed is a guide to the best path that guarantees true happiness.
text.3:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that those who prefer worldly life over the life of the hereafter, hinder others from the path of Allah, and desire that people turn away from the straight path that Allah has given to mankind, are in extreme error.

Various worldly affairs should not distract us from preparing ourselves for the life of the hereafter. However, worldly life should also not be completely ignored, as Allah says:

And seek, through what Allah has given you, the home of the Hereafter; and [yet], do not forget your share of the world. (al-Qashash/28: 77)

The disbelievers not only deny the Al-Quran, but also hinder others from following the correct path, which is preventing people from knowing the teachings of Islam and making it a guide in life. Thus, they are people who are misguided and try to mislead others, so their evil is multiplied.

They also strive with various deceptions to make the straight path shown by Allah crooked. They exchange the verses of Allah for what suits their desires and evil intentions. Thus, the mistakes they make are multiplied again. It is only fitting that they are afflicted with the wrath of Allah because they are misguided and disbelieving.
text.4:
In the previous verse, it was mentioned that the revelation of the Quran to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is a mercy for mankind. Then, in this verse, Allah also explains another of His mercies, which is the sending of messengers to a people using the language spoken by that people. This facilitates communication between the messengers and their people in order to provide explanations and guidance to those people.

However, even though the holy book has been revealed in their respective languages, and the messengers have spoken to them in the same language, there are still those among them who are reluctant to listen, understand, and follow it. Therefore, Allah leaves these people to stray, and Allah guides those whom He wills. Allah is All-Powerful and All-Wise.
text.5:
In this verse, Allah SWT shows that the messengers who were sent to mankind had the same task, which is to convey the verses of Allah to guide mankind to the right path, to bring them out of the darkness caused by ignorance, disbelief, and disobedience, to the bright light of faith, guidance, knowledge, and noble character. Allah recounts in this verse that the Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) was also sent to carry out this task, and was commanded to call his people. Allah says, "Bring your people out of darkness into light, call them to believe, and remind them of the days of Allah."

What is meant by "the days of Allah" are important events that have been experienced by previous peoples, such as the blessings of Allah that they received when they were freed from the slavery of Pharaoh, or the wrath and punishment of Allah that befell them because of their denial.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that "the days of Allah" contain signs of His Oneness and Power. These signs can only be understood by everyone who is patient and grateful.
text.6: In this verse, Allah SWT recounts the story of Prophet Musa (Moses) inviting his people to remember the blessings of Allah that had been bestowed upon them, namely when Allah saved them from the cruelty of Pharaoh and his followers, who had tortured them with severe torment, slaughtering their sons, and letting their daughters live. Then Prophet Musa reminded his people that all the experiences they had gone through were actually a very heavy trial from Allah towards them, to test their faith and obedience to Him.
text.7:
In this verse, Allah SWT reminds His servants once again to always be grateful for all the blessings He has bestowed upon them. If they do so, He will increase those blessings. Conversely, Allah also reminds those who deny His blessings and refuse to be grateful that He will inflict a severe punishment upon them.

Gratitude for Allah's mercy can be expressed in various ways. First, with sincere words from the heart; second, accompanied by actions, namely using that mercy for purposes that please Him.

In daily life, we can see that people who are generous and like to spend their wealth for the public good and to help others, generally never fall into poverty or misery. In fact, their sustenance constantly increases, their wealth grows, and their lives are happy, loved, and respected in society. Conversely, wealthy people who are stingy, or like to use their wealth for things that are not pleasing to Allah, such as gambling or collecting riba (interest), their wealth does not increase, but rather quickly diminishes. In addition to that, they are constantly hated and cursed by many people, and in the afterlife, they will receive a severe punishment.
text.8:
Allah SWT explains in this verse the words of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) when he said to his people that even if they and everyone on earth disbelieved in Allah and denied His blessings and mercy, it would not diminish His greatness and majesty. This is because Allah SWT is All-Sufficient and Praiseworthy, not needing their expressions of gratitude nor requiring their good deeds for His own benefit or to increase His greatness and glory. Their disbelief would only harm themselves, because Allah does not increase His blessings and mercy upon them. Allah says:

"Whoever does righteousness, it is for his [own] soul; and whoever does evil [does it] against it. And your Lord is never unjust to [His] servants." (Fushshilat/41: 46)
text.9:
In this verse, Allah swt asks mankind whether they have ever received news about previous peoples, as well as news about the events they experienced, for example, news about the people of Prophet Noah, the people of 'Âd and the people of Thamud, as well as the peoples who came after them, whom only Allah truly knows?

They denied the messengers even though they had brought clear proofs. They put their hands to their mouths to show their hatred for the messengers, saying, "Indeed, we deny what you have been commanded to convey to us." In addition to that, those peoples also said to the messengers that they were in doubt and not certain about the truth that the messengers were calling them to.
text.10:
In this verse, it is explained that because they expressed doubt regarding what was conveyed to them by the messengers, especially concerning the power of Allah swt, the messengers said to their people, "Is there doubt about Allah, Creator of the heavens and the earth? He calls you to forgive your sins, and He has postponed punishment for you until a time appointed by Him?"

Conversely, the people of each messenger said that the messengers, in their view, were ordinary people like them and had no advantages whatsoever. Therefore, there was no reason for them to become followers of the messengers. According to them, the messengers had turned them away from the religion inherited from their ancestors and prevented them from worshiping the idols that were the objects of worship of their ancestors. Therefore, they asked for clear proof from the messengers to demonstrate the truth of their appointment as messengers of Allah swt. In fact, the messengers had presented their respective miracles, which Allah had bestowed upon them as proof of their prophethood.
text.11:
To answer the questions and requests of their people, this verse mentions the words of the messengers to them, stating that indeed they were only human beings like their people, except that Allah had bestowed favor upon them, namely in the form of prophethood and messengership, accompanied by miracles that could only be used with the permission of Allah SWT. Therefore, it is not within the authority of a messenger to present miracles other than what Allah has bestowed upon him.

At the end of this verse, it is also shown that tawakal is a principle and attitude of life that must be held by every believer, once they have fulfilled their obligations to the best of their ability.
text.12: This verse explains the affirmation of the messengers to their people, that they have absolutely no reason not to put their trust in Allah SWT, because He has bestowed upon them abundant grace and blessings. Among these is that Allah SWT has shown them the straight path that leads them to the bright light of faith, so that they may obtain His pleasure in this world and the hereafter. Therefore, they will face all the threats of their people with patience, perseverance, and reliance on the Almighty. It is to Allah alone that the believers put their trust and surrender themselves. They do not feel intimidated or afraid of the threats of those who do not believe, because everything in this universe is subject to the power of Allah.
text.13:
In this verse, the continuation of the disbelievers' words towards the messengers is narrated, where they threatened the messengers with expulsion from their lands if they did not cease preaching the religion of Allah. The disbelievers presented the messengers with a choice: either accept the expulsion, or be willing to return to the religion they inherited from their ancestors, namely the religion of shirk and disbelief.

Furthermore, this verse explains that after the threat from the disbelievers, Allah SWT revealed to the messengers that He would surely destroy the unjust people. This revelation was a tremendous moral boost for each messenger who was carrying out his sacred duty, so that they would not feel intimidated in facing the unjust people.
text.14:
In this verse, Allah SWT mentions another of His promises to the messengers, that Allah will establish them in those lands, after the unjust people have vanished due to the torment that will be inflicted upon them. This promise will be fulfilled for those who are pious, who fear facing Allah with many sins, and who fear His threats and punishment.

It is clearly understood that Allah's promise mentioned in this verse reinforces His promise mentioned in the verse above, regarding the destruction of the unjust people. After they are destroyed and vanish from the face of the earth, then the messengers together with their respective communities who believe and are obedient to Allah will become the inhabitants of those lands, and they will live peacefully under the abundance of Allah's mercy and pleasure (rida).
text.15:
Those who believe in Allah, hoping for His pleasure and mercy, and fearing His threats and punishment, beseech Allah to grant them victory over their oppressive enemies. Allah answers their prayers. Thus, the people who are arbitrary and stubborn are destroyed.

Arbitrariness and stubbornness are characteristics of the arrogant, who want to rival the power and greatness of Allah. They do not heed the laws and regulations that Allah has bestowed upon His servants to regulate relationships between people, so that a harmonious life, mutual love, and mutual respect can be achieved. Therefore, they deserve to receive punishment from the All-Powerful and Most Merciful.
text.16: In this verse, it is emphasized that those who reject the truth by denying the messenger sent by Allah to them, even daring to threaten to expel him, are those who want to rival the power and greatness of Allah. They are stubborn, arrogant, and act arbitrarily. They are already in front of Hell, even in this worldly life, they feel as if they are on the edge of Hell, always restless, worried, and full of doubt. In the Hereafter, they will be thrown into Hell and given drinks of filthy water like pus. This is a punishment for those who do not heed the laws and guidance given by Allah to His servants.
text.17: In this verse, Allah swt describes how severe the punishment will be received or suffered by the unjust people in the Hereafter, namely punishment with the extremely hot fire of Hell. They will be given filthy drinks like pus, and they will drink that filthy water, but it will be very difficult for them to swallow it. In addition to that, the danger of death constantly threatens them from all directions, but their death is postponed by Allah, so that they may feel the pain of the torment that will be inflicted upon them.
text.18: If in the verses above Allah has explained the torment that the disbelievers will suffer in Hell, then in this verse He explains the great loss they will suffer, namely the reward for their good deeds in the world, if any, will be erased by Allah. Thus, they cannot feel any benefit from the good deeds they may have done in the world. Their deeds are likened by this verse to ashes blown away by a strong wind, disappearing without a trace. This state of affairs is a result of their error and deviation far from the guidance of Allah swt.
text.19:
In this verse, Allah swt mentions that He is the One who created this planet Earth with its sky (atmosphere) with truth ( *bi al-haqq*). Meaning, Allah created all of that not in vain, but full of knowledge and wisdom. Scientifically, our Earth and its atmosphere contain substances or materials that support the process of life. The Earth's atmosphere is 70% composed of nitrogen gas (N2), which is inert (harmless to living things), but is very necessary for the emergence of a life process, especially by the flora (plants). While 20% of our atmosphere is oxygen gas (O2), which is essential for the survival of all living things, because oxygen will provide energy for the metabolic processes of all creatures for their survival; through a process we know as respiration (breathing).

Our Earth itself is 70% water (H2O), a substance (chemical molecule) that is essential as a medium for the metabolic reaction processes for a life. The distance between the Earth and the sun is quite moderate, which is 92.9 million miles or about 139.35 million km; so that sunlight is able to catalyze (help) the life process. Both in humans (the process of vitamin D formation in the skin), animals, or plants (assimilation). The Earth's temperature at the equator is also very moderate, averaging only 28-350C.

Imagine other planets that are still in the solar system, such as the planet Mars, whose atmosphere is mostly methane gas (CH4) which is deadly, the distance from the sun is about 141.6 million miles or 212.40 million km; the surface temperature of the planet Mars (at the equator) is 0-10oC; so it's colder than Earth. Or the planet Venus with a very thick atmosphere and its distance from the sun is 67.2 million miles or 100.80 million km, but the temperature of the planet is quite cold due to the thick atmospheric blanket. The surface temperature of Venus at the equator is estimated at -32oC. While the planets Jupiter and Saturn, which are each at a distance from the sun of 483.4 million miles (725.10 million km) and 886.3 million miles (1329.45 million km) have an average surface temperature of the planet at the equator of -143oC. The atmosphere of Jupiter and Saturn is dominated by ammonia gas (NH3).

If Allah wills, the earth can easily be changed to conditions like those planets, and then all the creatures of this earth will die. Therefore, humans who have been made by Allah as His caliphs on this earth should utilize all of that in a good way and for good purposes, in accordance with His rules and provisions. However, if humans deviate from Allah's rules and provisions, then He will not let them commit injustice.

Then at the end of this verse, Allah swt affirms to His Messenger that if He wills, He will destroy his people and replace them with new creatures.

This affirmation is to remind the Messenger and his people who are obedient and believe in Allah, how great the sin of the disbelievers is, because with that disbelief they do not recognize Allah's power as the creator and maintainer of His creatures. If humans think about Allah's power and His mercy towards humans, surely they will come to the conviction that only Allah is entitled to be worshiped and praised and to be feared for His torment and punishment.
text.20: In this verse, Allah also affirms that destroying all of that is not difficult for Him, because He is the Creator and the Master of it. There is nothing that can prevent Him, if He wills to inflict punishment upon His servants.
text.21:
In this verse, Allah SWT describes the situation that will occur in the Plain of Gathering (Padang Mahsyar), where people are gathered after they are resurrected from their graves, to account for the good deeds and evil deeds that each person committed in the world.

It is mentioned in this verse that all people will gather before Allah in the Plain of Gathering, to be judged and to hear Allah's decision about their future fate. And after the reckoning is completed, and those who are sinful have been determined to be punished in hell, there arises awareness and regret from the people of weak faith who were deceived by the enticements of the arrogant people in this world who treated themselves as gods, and the people of weak faith as servants. At that time, those of weak faith say to the arrogant people who were once their followers while in the world, "We used to be your followers when we were in the world. Now, can you save us from Allah's torment and punishment, even just a little?"

Furthermore, in this verse, the answer of the arrogant people to this statement is mentioned, "If Allah had guided us, we would have been able to guide you as well. Now our situation is the same, we must choose between complaining and regretting our actions, or patiently accepting the fate that Allah has decreed for us. We will never find a place to escape from His torment and punishment."

This verse clearly illustrates how great the mistakes that both groups have made are. The first group, namely those who are weak in faith, have allowed themselves to become the playthings of the arrogant people in this world, and have enslaved themselves to them, and in the afterlife it turns out that those they glorified are unable to defend themselves from Allah's torment, let alone defend others whom they have enslaved in this world. While the second group has deceived the weak in this world and acted like gods. In the afterlife, they are also demanded by their followers to defend and save them from Allah's torment, but they are powerless, facing the power and greatness of Allah SWT.
text.22:
In this verse, Allah mentions the confession of Satan before Allah, after the reckoning (hisab) is completed in the Gathering Place (Padang Mahsyar). Satan constantly tempts and misleads humans from the right path, presenting things in such a way that those who are tempted see evil as a good and praiseworthy deed. And besides that, Satan also makes promises to those who are tempted, namely the advantages they will gain if they fulfill his invitation. However, he is unable to fulfill these promises.

Satan's confession after the reckoning in the Gathering Place is completed is addressed to those whom he has misled in this world, both the weak who have enslaved themselves to other than Allah, and the strong and arrogant who have considered themselves as gods. In his confession, Satan tells them that indeed Allah had promised them a true promise, and He is able to fulfill His promise. Satan also made promises to them, but he is unable to keep them. Satan has no power whatsoever over them; he only calls people to something that is not true, and they simply obey his call without using their minds. Therefore, it is the humans who are at fault. They should not blame him, but rather blame themselves. Satan can never help them from Allah's torment and punishment, and they cannot help him either. Indeed, Satan has never justified the actions of humans in associating partners with Allah."

Such will be the situation in the Hereafter. The strong and arrogant in this world, who have misled the weak, disown the weak who have become victims of their misguidance. Furthermore, Satan, who has tempted and misled both groups, also disowns the fate of those who have become victims of his false temptations. All are powerless in the face of Allah's judgment upon them.

At the end of this verse, Allah reaffirms that those who are unjust, whether to themselves or to others, will certainly receive a painful punishment, as a reward for their injustice.
text.23:
In this verse, Allah mentions again the happiness that will be obtained by those who believe in Allah and consistently do good deeds, that in the Hereafter they will be placed in Paradise, a very beautiful garden under whose trees flow clear rivers. They will remain there enjoying a happy life, with Allah's permission, as a reward for their faith and good deeds during their life in the world. There they will greet each other with, "Salam," which means peace from all calamities. For those of us who are still living in this world, the Islamic religion teaches us to use the greeting "Assalamualaikum" which means "may you always be in peace." This is the best teaching to educate people to be willing and happy when others obtain happiness and prosperity in life, just as they feel happy when they themselves obtain happiness and prosperity, and far from feelings of envy and hasad. Hoping that others will experience misery or loss and hoping for the disappearance of happiness or goodness from someone is a trait that is greatly hated by the Islamic religion.

In this regard, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"None of you truly believes until he loves for his brother (fellow believer) what he loves for himself." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Anas bin Malik)
text.24:
The parable mentioned in this verse is a parable concerning good words, for example, words containing the teachings of Tawhid, such as "La ilaha illallah" or other words that invite people to goodness and prevent them from evil. Such words are likened to a good tree, its roots firmly embedded in the earth. The roots of a tree have two main functions: (1) to absorb water and nutrients from the soil and (2) to support the tree's uprightness. If the roots can no longer take nutrients from the soil, the tree will slowly die. Meanwhile, the roots of a tree that function well will be able to channel nutrients from the soil to the upper parts of the tree, and the tree's growth will proceed well. Its branches are lush and tower into the sky. Hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him):

From Abdullah bin Umar (may Allah be pleased with him), he said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said, "Among the types of trees, there is a tree that never sheds its leaves. That tree is a parable for a Muslim. Tell me, what is that tree?" People thought that the tree was a tree that grows in the forest. Abdullah said, "According to me, that tree is a date palm tree. But I was ashamed to say it." Then the companions said, "Tell us what that tree is, O Messenger of Allah!" He replied, "That tree is a date palm tree." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

The religion of Islam teaches its followers to get used to using good words, which are beneficial for themselves and beneficial for others. A person's words show their character and personality, as well as their manners and etiquette. Conversely, every Muslim must avoid obscene words and language that can cause disgust to those who hear them.
text.25:
In this verse, it is depicted that a good tree always yields its fruit to every human being, with the permission of its Lord. As for the plant growth process, various nutrients are required in quite a number of varieties. According to the amount needed, these nutrients are divided into macronutrients, which are needed in large quantities, and micronutrients, which are needed in small quantities, but their presence is absolutely necessary. To reach the point of producing fruit, the roots must be able to supply all the needs of these nutrients in sufficient and balanced amounts. There are some nutrients that, if supplied in excess of their needs, will become poisonous to the plant and can cause death to the plant (for example, iron for rice plants). Therefore, humans who benefit from the tree should be grateful to Allah because, in essence, the knowledge they have acquired through someone is a gift and mercy from Allah swt.

Similarly, good words that we say to others, for example, in providing useful knowledge, will benefit many people. Everyone who obtains knowledge from a teacher must be grateful to Allah because, in essence, the knowledge they have acquired through someone is a gift and mercy from Allah swt.

Parents in the household must always use good and polite words, and avoid dirty and rude speech, because these words will be imitated by their children.
text.26:
In this verse, an analogy is given for bad words and sentences, namely utterances that contain disbelief and polytheism or that invite to sinful acts. These bad words are likened to a bad tree, whose roots are uprooted from the earth, so that the tree cannot stand firmly, cannot bear leaves or fruit. This means it cannot provide fruit or other benefits to humans, but only causes harm, if the tree falls and strikes them. Bad words can only cause sin, and arouse anger and hatred. In a hadith narrated by Abu Hathim as a marfu' hadith, that *syajarah khabitsah* (bad tree) is *handhalah* whose fruit tastes bitter.

People who cannot control their emotions often utter bad words, which endanger themselves and endanger others. Likewise, people who are drunk and whose minds are impaired, like to utter bad words. That is why Islam teaches patience because patience encourages a person to control their emotions. Islam also forbids a person from things that damage the mind, such as drinking alcohol and others.
text.27:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that He strengthens the believers with good and firm words, both in this life and in the Hereafter. Thus, there is a reciprocal relationship between faith and good, firm words. Faith encourages a person to always use good and firm words. Conversely, good words can maintain the steadfastness of a person's faith.

In this verse further, Allah swt affirms that He allows to stray those who are unjust and who like to act according to their own desires, without regard for correct rules, including uttering bad words that lead to disbelief (kufr), polytheism (shirk), disobedience (maksiat), and so on.
text.28:
This verse is presented in the form of a question, but not to be answered. Rather, it serves as a warning to Muslims so that they never act and behave like the disbelievers. They should always be obedient, submissive, and compliant with Allah's commands and cease all His prohibitions. If they deny Allah, they will surely be punished in this world and the Hereafter, as was inflicted upon the disbelievers.

According to Ibn Abbas, the "those who have exchanged the favor of Allah" in this verse refers to the disbelievers of Mecca. They were granted various blessings that Allah did not give to other nations. Mecca was made a sacred land, a land of guaranteed security, and the location of the Kaaba, which is visited by people from all corners of the world every year. Allah SWT brought water, food, and fruits to that barren land. An even greater blessing was the appointment of Muhammad from among their own people as the final prophet and messenger, bringing the religion of Allah, which serves as guidance and a way of life for all mankind.

All these blessings that had been bestowed upon them were denied. They even tortured the Prophet Muhammad SAW and the Muslims and hindered the spread of Islam. Therefore, Allah SWT inflicted punishment and torment upon them in the form of a long and severe drought, causing many of them to die of starvation. According to a narration, some of them even ate bones because there was no more food to eat.

Allah explains that they are the ones who have exchanged the favor of Allah and have placed their people, who became their followers, in a place full of misery, which is Hell, blazing fiercely, whose fuel is stones and people.

From this verse, it is understood that Allah SWT commands mankind to always be grateful for His blessings by following His commands and ceasing His prohibitions. All humans and creatures are very dependent on these blessings, both in the form of outward blessings and inward or unseen blessings.
text.29:
This verse is presented in the form of a question, but not to be answered. Rather, it serves as a warning to Muslims so that they never act and behave like the disbelievers. They should always be obedient, submissive, and compliant with Allah's commands and cease all His prohibitions. If they deny Allah, they will surely be punished in this world and the hereafter, just as the disbelievers are punished.

According to Ibn Abbas, the "those who have exchanged the favor of Allah" in this verse refers to the disbelievers of Mecca. They were granted various blessings that Allah did not give to other nations. Mecca was made a sacred land, a land of guaranteed security, and the location of the Kaaba, which is visited by people from all corners of the world every year. Allah SWT brought water, food, and fruits to that barren land. An even greater blessing was the appointment of Muhammad from their own people as the final prophet and messenger, bringing the religion of Allah, which serves as guidance and a way of life for all mankind.

All these blessings that had been bestowed upon them were denied. They even tortured the Prophet Muhammad SAW and the Muslims and hindered the spread of Islam. Therefore, Allah SWT inflicted punishment and torment upon them in the form of a long and severe drought, causing many of them to die of starvation. According to a narration, some of them even ate bones because there was no more food to eat.

Allah explains that they are the ones who have exchanged the favor of Allah and have placed their people, who are their followers, in a place full of misery, namely Hell, which is blazing, and whose fuel is stones and people.

From this verse, it is understood that Allah SWT commands mankind to always be grateful for His blessings by following His commands and ceasing His prohibitions. All humans and creatures are very dependent on these blessings, both in the form of outward blessings and inward or unseen blessings.
text.30:
This verse explains the second and third actions that caused Allah to inflict a painful punishment upon them.

The second reason is the act of associating partners with Allah (shirk). Included in this action are:

1. Acknowledging that God is multiple.

2. Worshipping others besides worshipping Allah.

3. Acknowledging that something other than Allah has power and authority like the power and authority of Allah SWT.

Associating partners with Allah was the belief of the Arabs during the Jahiliyyah (Age of Ignorance). They had objects of worship besides Allah. Some of these objects of worship were in the form of statues that they made, some of which they placed around the Kaaba. They believed in divination and fortune-telling. If they wanted to do something important or take a long journey, they would go to the Kaaba and ask its caretakers to hold a lottery. The result of this lottery would determine whether they would do the work or take the long journey or not.

The third reason is that the disbelievers tried to mislead people from the path of Allah. They hindered, and even killed, people who performed good deeds or followed the religion of Islam.

The three types of actions above are major sins. Therefore, Allah SWT commanded the Prophet Muhammad to convey His stern warning to mankind. If they still disbelieve, let them do as they please, enjoy themselves, and commit destruction on earth for a certain time, until Allah inflicts a severe punishment upon them.

This is affirmed by the word of Allah SWT:

Say, "Enjoy yourselves in your disbelief a little; indeed, you are of the companions of the Fire." (az-Zumar/39: 8)
text.31:
In this verse, Allah swt commands the Muslims to perform good deeds that can bring happiness to people in worldly and hereafter life. These deeds are:

1. Performing salat (prayer).

2. Spending a portion of the wealth that Allah swt has bestowed.

Allah swt commands the Muslims to establish salat because salat is the pillar of religion, as the Prophet saw said:

Salat is the pillar of religion; whoever establishes it has established religion, and whoever abandons it has destroyed religion. (Narrated by al-Baihaqi from Umar bin al-Khaththab)

A person who is obedient and always performs salat according to the teachings of the Al-Quran is a person who is pure in body and soul, because salat prevents the person who performs it from committing vile and forbidden deeds, as Allah swt says:

...and establish prayer. Indeed, prayer prohibits immorality and wrongdoing, and the remembrance of Allah is greater. And Allah knows that which you do. (al-Ankabut/29: 45)

And Allah swt says:

He has certainly succeeded who purifies himself, And mentions the name of his Lord and prays. (al-Ala/87: 14-15)

The first deed of a servant that Allah will reckon on the Day of Judgment is salat. If a servant's salat is good, then his deeds are good, but if his salat is bad or he does not perform it, then all the rewards of his other deeds are bad and ruined.

Rasulullah saw said:

The first deed of a servant that Allah will reckon on the Day of Judgment is salat. If the deed of salat is good, then all his deeds are good, and if the deed of salat is bad, then all his deeds are bad. (Narrated by ath-Thabrani from Anas bin Malik)

Allah swt even affirms that those who always perform salat are the ones who will inherit the Paradise of Firdaus in the Hereafter, as He says:

And they who carefully maintain their prayers - Those are the inheritors Who will inherit al-Firdaus. They will abide therein eternally. (al-Muminun/23: 9-11)

Performing salat means performing salat continuously, according to the time that has been determined by religion, complete with its conditions and pillars, accompanied by khusyuk (humility) and sincerity.

Allah also commands the believers to spend a portion of the wealth that Allah has bestowed upon them, before the Day of Judgment comes, which is the day when all doors of repentance have been closed, not a single sin can be redeemed, even if it is redeemed with gold filling the earth. There is no close friend who can help and no one who can save and provide assistance, including children and grandchildren. Allah swt says:

So today no ransom will be taken from you or from those who disbelieved. (al-hadid/57: 15)

And Allah swt says:

O you who have believed, spend from that which We have provided for you before there comes a Day in which there is no exchange and no friendship and no intercession. And the disbelievers - they are the wrongdoers. (al-Baqarah/2: 254)

Those who are freed from the torment of the Day of Judgment are only those who, during their lives in the world, perform righteous deeds, are happy to give charity, so that their hearts are pure and clean and content with what Allah will give them later. Allah swt says:

The Day when there will not benefit [anyone] wealth or children, But only one who comes to Allah with a sound heart. (asy-Syuara/26: 88-89)

Being happy to spend wealth is a reflection of the true Muslim personality, as someone who has surrendered himself, his wealth, and his life to religion, solely to seek the pleasure of Allah swt. This deed is also a manifestation of gratitude to Allah who has bestowed His blessings that are countless. To those who are grateful for blessings, Allah will add more blessings than the blessings that have been given.

Conversely, the characteristic of not being happy to spend a portion of the wealth that Allah has bestowed is a reflection of the personality of those who deny Allah and His Messenger, and a reflection of ingratitude towards Allah's blessings. They feel that everything they have obtained is solely due to their own hard work. With such an attitude, it means that they have been unjust to themselves. The consequence of being unjust to oneself is that one will no longer receive additional blessings from Allah, and they will even be afflicted with a painful torment in this world and in the Hereafter. Being unjust to others means that one does not want to give or release the rights of others that are in his wealth. Being unjust to the community around him means disrupting the interests and good relations that have been established in the community.

Even from this verse, it is understood that those who are stingy and do not want to spend a portion of their wealth are arrogant and proud people. Because they feel that they are able to overcome all kinds of difficulties they face, including the difficulties and disasters that will befall them on the Day of Judgment. They feel that they no longer need additional blessings and help from Allah, both in this world and in the Hereafter.

Spending wealth in Islam has several forms:

1. Spending wealth for the sustenance of oneself, children, relatives, and wife.

2. Spending wealth to fulfill obligations, such as zakat on wealth and zakat fitrah.

3. Spending wealth for sunnah (voluntary) infaq.

Spending wealth for the sustenance of one's wife, relatives, and to fulfill obligatory sustenance is an obligation that religion has established on believers, and its provisions are in the verses of the Al-Quran and the hadith of the Prophet. While sunnah infaq that is given for the public interest and to exalt the word of Allah is categorized as amal jariah, which is infaq or charity whose reward will not be cut off, even though the person who gives the infaq has died, as long as the infaq provides benefit.

The giving of obligatory infaq, sunnah infaq, and sustenance must be accompanied by a sincere intention, solely done to seek the pleasure of Allah, far from the characteristics of riya (showing off), wanting to be praised and flattered by fellow human beings. Therefore, Allah leaves it to humans how best to give wealth to those who are entitled to receive it, so that it produces rewards from Allah's side. If he is worried that riya will arise in his heart, then he may give the wealth secretly, unknown to people. If he wants his actions to be imitated by others, then he may also give his wealth openly.

Muslims should remember that wealth is in essence the property of Allah. He bestows it upon humans so that they can carry out their duties as servants of Allah as long as they live in this world. Therefore, if someone has obtained wealth and it has exceeded his needs, he should spend it on those who are entitled to receive it.
text.32:
Allah, the One and Almighty, bestows countless blessings upon His servants. Among them are:

Allah, the Most Great, Whose knowledge encompasses all things, explains that He is the One who created the heavens and the earth, whose creation is far greater and more difficult than the creation of mankind, which is always witnessed and observed by humans, and in both there are lessons and benefits. The heavens are an expanse of space that is infinitely vast and large, containing celestial bodies in the form of countless planets, each moving according to a predetermined orbit, following the laws established by Allah swt. Not a single planet fails to follow these laws, because failing to follow the established laws would mean destruction for all the planets. If one contemplates, observes, and studies the neat and orderly arrangement of space, one will feel the insignificance of mankind and increasingly feel the majesty and greatness of its Creator.

Allah also created the earth, which is one of the planets in space, where humans live, reside, and prepare themselves before experiencing true life in the hereafter. The surface of the earth is covered with a variety of plants, with a variety of fruits that are useful and beneficial to humans. In the bowels of the earth there are various kinds of minerals. All of this was created by Allah for mankind.

He is the One who sends down rain that comes from water vapor and becomes clouds. He drives the clouds with the wind to a certain place, until they become dark and dense, then change and fall as rain that waters the surface of the earth. With the rain, plants grow and flourish, then become large, bloom, and bear fruit, as Allah swt says:

And you see the earth barren, but when We send down rain upon it, it stirs [to life] and swells and puts forth [plants] of every beautiful kind. (al-hajj/22: 5)

And the word of Allah swt:

[He] who has made for you the earth as a bed [spread out] and inserted therein for you roadways and sent down from the sky, rain and produced thereby varieties of plants - each separate. (thaha/20: 53)

Scientifically (kauniyah), this verse explains the biospheric cycle. Allah reaffirms His power in regulating life on this earth. From the water poured from the sky, fertile gardens emerge that produce fruits, all of which are intended as sustenance for mankind. Then, in the verse, it continues with "And He subjected for you the ships," and also "And He subjected for you the rivers." The word "subjected" in both sentences above is translated from the Arabic word *sakhkhara*. This implies to humans to use their minds (technology) in making or creating ships that are able to sail on the seas, or in managing rivers, as places for navigation or other purposes.

If humans use their minds by using natural science (Allah's provisions) so that they can find for themselves Allah's provisions that Allah uses to control ships, then those humans can strive to make human will in line with His will and His provisions.

Allah's provision shows how to construct a ship so that it can lift its body and its cargo so that it does not sink. Allah's provision shows that an object floating in water will displace water as much as the contents of the object. The weight of the water displaced by the object will be proportional to the upward pressure experienced by the object. By making a hollow ship, a large outer volume will be achieved, but the weight is small because it is hollow. Therefore, the body of the ship and its cargo are able to be lifted by the upward force until it floats.

By using a driving engine similar to a land vehicle but has been adjusted in such a way, then the ship, in addition to being able to float, is also able to move in the desired direction. This is the explanation from the perspective of a scientist.

Allah explains this so that humans know how great His power is in regulating life and life on the surface of this earth and the blessings that have been bestowed upon humans. For humans who like to pay attention to the occurrence of rain, plants, and the life processes on the surface of this earth, they will know how high the value of Allah's law is and how vast His knowledge is, which applies constantly, incessantly until the time He has determined. Allah also commands humans to pay attention to the water they drink so that they are grateful, as He says:

Have you seen the water that you drink? Is it you who brought it down from the clouds, or is it We who bring it down? If We willed, We could make it bitter, so why are you not grateful? (al-Waqiah/56: 68-70)

Allah subjecting ships (arks) for humans means giving humans the ability to make ships and make them able to float on the surface of the water and sail to the place they want, taking them to all corners of the world. Allah swt subjected the sea for humans so that the sea can be sailed by ships carrying all their needs, as He says:

And a sign for them is that We carried their forefathers in a laden ship. And We created for them similar to it things that they ride. (Yasin/36: 41-42)

With the ship, humans also enjoy sailing. With the ship, they also earn a living, catch fish, look for marine products, and look for minerals that are priceless. All of this is a blessing from Allah to mankind.

Allah subjects rivers for humans, such as giving the ability to dam and channel them for agricultural purposes, and to change the swift current of water into a useful source of energy, such as water wheels and electric currents. Rivers can also function as highways through which ships pass and are the lifeblood of trade. To shorten river traffic, humans make canals that connect one river to another, and one ocean to another. Dirty river water can be cleaned, so that it can become drinking water that is very necessary.
text.33:
Likewise, as a blessing from Allah swt to mankind is that He has subjected the sun and the moon for mankind, that is, making the sun and the moon continuously move around their orbits, which produces light and darkness that are beneficial for the life and existence of creatures. With the sun and the moon remaining constant, as well as other planets, moving around their orbits, the occurrence of a massive collision between the planets in the sky will be avoided, as Allah says:

"And the moon - We have determined for it phases, until it returns [appearing] like the old date stalk. It is not allowable for the sun to overtake the moon, nor can the night outstrip the day. Each is swimming in an orbit." (Yasin/36: 39-40)

The existence of orbits that are continuously traversed by each planet has paved the way for humans to reach the moon, providing a great possibility for humans to strive to reach other planets. Through these orbits, humans can also place satellites that can be used for the benefit of mankind, such as to know the weather conditions, to facilitate telecommunications, and so on, so that relations between countries that were initially felt to be far away are now felt to be closer.

Allah swt also subjected the day and night for mankind. The day can be used by humans as a place to strive, to do good deeds, and to socialize. While the night can be used as a time to rest from fatigue after striving during the day. Allah says:

"And out of His mercy He has made for you the night and the day that you may rest therein and [by day] seek from His bounty and perhaps you will be grateful." (al-Qashash/28: 73)

In this verse, Allah also uses the word *sakhkhara* (subjected), which indicates to us to use our intellect in utilizing both the sun, the moon, and the phenomena of night and day. Thus, *sakhkhara* contains a command to develop technology, solar calendars or lunar calendars, and solar energy. It also contains a command to use both the sun or the moon for navigation purposes in sailing and aviation, and so on. Likewise, using night and day to know or measure our biological clock. This is the explanation from the perspective of scientists.

It is also from Allah's blessings that He has provided for mankind everything they need, whether requested or not, because Allah has created the heavens and the earth for mankind. He provides for mankind everything that exists, so that it can be used and utilized whenever desired. Sometimes, mankind themselves do not know what their basic needs are, without which they cannot live or achieve their goals. Such needs are still bestowed upon them by Allah even without being asked for. There are also other forms of human needs that cannot be obtained except through effort and prayer, therefore human effort is required to obtain them.

Allah SWT has bestowed so many blessings upon mankind that if anyone wanted to count them, they would certainly not be able to. Therefore, every human being should be grateful for the blessings that Allah SWT has given by obeying all His commands and not doing things that are forbidden by Him. Being grateful for Allah's blessings, which is obligatory for mankind, is not something that Allah SWT needs. Allah is All-Sufficient, not needing anything from mankind, but most people are very unjust and deny the blessings that have been given to them.

In these verses, Allah swt commands the Prophet Muhammad to convey to his ummah the story of when Prophet Ibrahim prayed to his Lord, so that the prayer becomes a lesson and example for the Arabs at that time, because Ibrahim a.s. was their ancestor and origin. The prayer is: "Our Lord, make this city of Mecca a safe, peaceful, and prosperous city, and protected from war and enemy attacks." Prophet Ibrahim's prayer was answered by God, and He has made the city of Mecca and its surroundings a safe land and place for those who are there. In that land, it is forbidden to shed blood, persecute people, kill animals, and cut down plants that are there.

Allah says:

"Have they not seen that We have made (Mecca) a secure sanctuary, while people all around them are being snatched away? Then do they believe in falsehood and deny the blessings of Allah?" (al-Ankabut/29: 67)

The Arabs and the people who live around the Arabian Peninsula, from ancient times until now, still regard the holy land as sacred and respect it. The Arabs in the past were known as a nation that felt humiliated if they could not seek revenge for the murder or persecution committed by a person or a tribe against a member of their tribe. Seeking revenge was a sacred obligation to defend the honor of their tribe that had been tarnished. Therefore, they would seek revenge at every opportunity they could. Except if they met in the holy land, they would not seek revenge. They waited outside the holy land. After their enemy came out of the holy land, then they would carry out their revenge.

Likewise, the holy land is respected and protected from the evil intentions of people who want to destroy the Kaaba and defile it. As was once done and experienced by Abrahah, the governor of Ethiopia and his army. Abrahah, who was a Christian, was able to conquer Yemen, which was Jewish. He intended to develop Christianity in Yemen and make Yemen the center of Christianity in the Arabian Peninsula. He also knew that the people in the Arabian Peninsula greatly respected the Kaaba. Therefore, he wanted to divert people's attention from respecting and visiting the Kaaba to respecting and visiting a place or building in Yemen. To fulfill his desire, a large and magnificent church was built in Yemen, but the people of the Arabian Peninsula were not interested in visiting, let alone respecting the building. Therefore, Abrahah became angry, so he prepared an army riding elephants to attack Mecca and destroy the Kaaba. Even though he and his army did not receive any resistance from the people of Mecca at that time, Allah swt destroyed Abrahah and his army until they were scattered.

The event of the destruction of Abrahah and his army when attacking Mecca is described by Allah swt in His word:

"Have you not considered, [O Muhammad], how your Lord dealt with the companions of the elephant? Did He not make their plan a failure? And He sent against them birds in flocks, striking them with stones of hard clay, and He made them like eaten straw." (al-Fil/105: 1-5)

In the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad saw, it is explained a lot about the establishment of Mecca as a holy land. Even in the hadith narrated by al-Bukhari, it is emphasized that the land of Mecca has been designated by Allah as a holy land since Allah created the heavens and the earth:

From Shafiyah binti Syaibah, she said, "I heard the Messenger of Allah saw preaching on the day of the conquest of Mecca, he said, "O people, indeed Allah has made Mecca a holy land on the day of the creation of the heavens and the earth, so He has forbidden it until the Day of Judgment, its plants may not be cut, its animals may not be hunted, and its lost property may not be taken except by someone who will announce it." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

The Prophet Muhammad saw once prayed to Allah swt that Medina also be made a holy land. The prayer was uttered by the Messenger of Allah when the Muslims faced him at the beginning of the fruit season, to present the fruits to him. When he held the fruits that were given, he prayed:

"O Lord, indeed Ibrahim is Your servant, Your beloved, and Your prophet. Likewise, I am Your servant and Your prophet. Indeed, Ibrahim has prayed to You for Mecca, and indeed I also pray for Medina as he prayed to You for Mecca and the like." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Ibrahim also prayed that he and his descendants be kept away by Allah swt from the act of worshiping idols, because that act misleads people from the right path to the wrong path. Furthermore, Ibrahim explained that whoever among his descendants followed him, namely believed in Allah with all his heart, purified obedience and submission only to Allah alone, those are the people who follow his religion. Conversely, whoever among his descendants does not follow his religion, and does not follow the guidance of Allah that he has conveyed, then Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Merciful, Most Accepting of Repentance by guiding people to the right path.

This means that whoever acknowledges himself as a follower of Prophet Ibrahim a.s., surely he adheres to a religion based on monotheism, acknowledging that God is One, does not beget, is not born or created, and is not associated with anything, as the confession of adherents of religions who state that the origin of their religion is the religion of Prophet Ibrahim. It is impossible for a religion to claim to be a follower of Ibrahim's teachings when they associate partners with Allah, and do not purify obedience and submission to Allah alone.

This prayer of Prophet Ibrahim was not entirely granted by Allah because many of his descendants were disobedient to Allah, besides many who believed, and some were even appointed as prophets and messengers.

In the previous verse, Allah swt explained that after Prophet Ibrahim was appointed as a prophet and messenger, he also prayed that his descendants in the future would also be appointed as prophets and messengers, but Allah swt answered that not all of Prophet Ibrahim's prayers were granted by God, because those who are unjust, even if they are the children of a prophet and messenger, it is impossible to be appointed as prophets and messengers, like their father and grandfather. Allah swt says:

"And [mention, O Muhammad], when Abraham was tried by his Lord with commands and he fulfilled them. [Allah] said, "Indeed, I will make you a leader for the people." [Abraham] said, "And of my descendants?" [Allah] said, "My covenant does not include the wrongdoers." (al-Baqarah/2: 124)

From this verse, it can be understood that Muslims are prohibited from appointing unjust people as leaders who will take care of their affairs. Those who will be appointed as leaders should be people who still have a pure soul, like to do good deeds, carry out Allah's commands, and stop His prohibitions.
