text.37:
This verse explains the moment when Ibrahim (peace be upon him) was about to return to Palestine to see his wife Sarah, leaving his wife Hajar and his young son Ismail in Mecca, in the middle of a barren desert, without being accompanied by anyone and without provisions for his family that he left behind. At that time, he prayed to the Most Gracious God, asking that his family be protected and saved from all dangers and disasters that might befall them.

Ibrahim (peace be upon him) was a prophet and messenger sent to call King Namrud, the king of Babylon, and his people to follow the religion of Allah. After receiving torture, obstacles, and threats from King Namrud and his followers, Ibrahim left Babylon and finally settled in Palestine, with his wife Sarah and his wife's helper, a woman named Hajar. Because Sarah was a barren woman, Ibrahim (peace be upon him) did not have a son, even though he was already old. Nevertheless, his desire to have a son remained a dream that he always longed for. Therefore, he married his wife's helper, Hajar, after obtaining permission and approval from Sarah. From that marriage, a son named Ismail was born, and with that birth, Ibrahim's dream that he had always wanted was fulfilled.

Ibrahim's affection for his son Ismail and his increasing love for Hajar caused feelings of anxiety and jealousy in Sarah. Anxious because she was worried that Ibrahim's love for her would diminish, and jealous because she herself could not fulfill Ibrahim's desire to have a son as his successor, while her helper Hajar could fulfill her husband's desire. Sarah conveyed her feelings to her husband Ibrahim, and asked him very much to take and distance Hajar and her son Ismail from her. That way, she would no longer see Hajar's happiness and Ismail's growing up. Ibrahim could feel how deep his love was for Sarah. He was also worried that Sarah would be sad if her request was not granted. Therefore, Ibrahim granted Sarah's request. So he took Hajar and his son, the young Ismail, walking following his camel without knowing his destination, in a state of pity and emotion remembering the fate that his wife and son would experience later. In such a state, without realizing it, he arrived in an area that was foreign to him, an area located between barren rocky hills, which is now called the city of Mecca.

At that time, Mecca was a lowland desert area that had not been inhabited by anyone. No water source was found. According to a hadith narrated by al-Bukhari, there was a tree in that place, and under that tree Ibrahim and his family took shelter and rested from the long journey from Palestine to Mecca now.

After Ibrahim accompanied Hajar and his son in that place for several days, he remembered his wife Sarah whom he had left in Palestine. Wanting to return to Palestine, he also did not have the heart to leave Hajar and his son. In such a state, he decided to return to Palestine and ask for Hajar's approval. When he asked for Hajar's approval and willingness, Hajar asked Ibrahim, "Did Allah command you to place me in this desolate and barren area?" Ibrahim replied, "Yes." Hajar replied, "If so, He (Allah) will not neglect us."

Then Ibrahim departed for Palestine, to see his wife Sarah and leave his wife and his young son Ismail in that place, in the middle of the scorching sun of the desert, without a house to take shelter, and sufficient supplies, except for a waterskin of water to quench their thirst. When Hajar and her son arrived at a place, when all their supplies and drinking water had run out, her son Ismail cried from thirst, while her breast milk no longer flowed. She intended to find water, and she laid her son down under the tree where she took shelter. She went wherever she thought there was water, but she did not find a single drop. So, without realizing it, she had run back and forth seven times between the hills of Safa and Marwah, but she still had not obtained even a single drop of water. So, with feelings of sadness and despair, she returned to the place where she had left her son. At that time, Ismail was crying from thirst while hitting his feet on the ground. Hajar then prayed, surrendering herself to the Most Gracious God.

In such a state, Ibrahim, who was continuing his journey to Palestine, remembered his wife and son whom he had left behind and the fate that they might be suffering, because it was estimated that the food and water he had left had run out. Then he prayed as contained in the verse, "O my Lord, I have settled some of my descendants, namely my wife and my son Ismail, who will continue my descendants, in a valley of barren and desolate desert, near the place where the Kaaba will be built, Your house later, which is respected, which You will forbid people from defiling its honor, and which You will make its surrounding area a haram area, that is, it is forbidden to fight and shed blood in that land."

The prayer of Ibrahim and his wife Hajar was answered by God. At that time, water gushed out of the ground from the former impact of the feet of his son Ismail who was crying. At that moment, Hajar felt grateful to Allah for His infinite grace, and hope arose in her heart for the survival of herself and her son, and she gave that water to her son Ismail to drink. Because she was worried that the water would run out and disappear back into the sand, she collected the water with her hands, saying, "Zam! Zam! (Gather! Gather!)" And the water gathered, not drying up until now and is called the Zamzam Well.

With the existence of the Zamzam Well in that place, many people who passed by asked for water there. When Bani Jurhum saw the existence of a water source in that place, they asked Hajar for permission to live together there, and Hajar granted that request. Since then, life began in that barren area, and more and more newcomers settled there. Finally, a country and civilization arose, so that the area became a trade route between west and east.

After Ismail grew up, he married one of the women of Bani Jurhum, the new arrivals, who later gave birth to descendants who were the forerunners of the inhabitants of that country. Those descendants multiplied, inhabiting the land of Mecca and its surroundings. From the descendants of Ismail, the Prophet Muhammad would later be born, as the last prophet and messenger of Allah.

In the verse above, it is further explained that Ibrahim (peace be upon him) prayed to God to preserve his descendants who were in Mecca, making them people who obediently perform prayers, enslaving and submitting themselves to God. He also asked that God make the hearts of people tend, love, and be affectionate towards his descendants, be given sustenance, and bring food and fruit to that barren land, because in that land it is impossible for plants to grow that are needed as food.

The prayer of Prophet Ibrahim was answered by Allah SWT. It is proven that from ancient times until now, many people have visited the Baitullah to perform Hajj and Umrah, and to see the remains of the legacy and struggle of the Prophet Muhammad SAW and his companions. Likewise, various kinds of necessities needed by the inhabitants of that country are brought to that barren land, such as food, fruit, and clothing to luxury goods.

The granting of multiple gifts is affirmed in the word of Allah SWT:

And they say, "If we were to follow the guidance with you, we would be driven out of our land." Have We not established for them a safe sanctuary to which are brought fruits of all kinds as provision from Us? But most of them do not know. (al-Qashash/28: 57)

Allah SWT bestows abundant sustenance and wealth upon the inhabitants and the land of Arabia so that they may be grateful for Allah's blessings by guarding the Baitullah, carrying out His commands, and stopping His prohibitions.

From this verse, it can be understood that everything obtained during life in this world is for the purpose of worshiping God. With the results obtained, the implementation of Allah's commands and the cessation of His prohibitions can be perfected, not solely for personal interests and pleasures.
text.38:
Furthermore, Prophet Ibrahim prayed, "Our Lord, indeed You know all that is hidden in our hearts, including all that is implied and etched within them. You also know all that we say and declare, including the prayers that we have raised to You. There is nothing that You do not know, whether on earth or in the heavens, because You alone created, possess, and manage all of it. Accept our prayer, O our Lord."

This verse teaches Muslims the proper ways to pray according to religious guidelines, namely, to pray with a pure heart, full of conviction in the greatness and power of Allah, and that the content of the prayer reflects the desire to perfect one's servitude to God, not to achieve some ambition for personal interest and pleasure and to the detriment of others. The prayer that Prophet Ibrahim requested was aimed at God making him and his descendants obedient servants of Allah, and that his descendants be given sustenance, so that with that sustenance they could perfect their servitude to Allah. With that sustenance, they could also defend and develop the religion of Allah and become servants and *khadam* of the Kaaba, the House of Allah.
text.39:
Ibrahim (peace be upon him) offered praise to Allah, Lord of the Universe, who had bestowed upon him two of the best sons, at a time when he and his wife were old, no longer able to have children. His wife Sarah had even despaired and felt it was impossible for her to have a child. It was at that time that he was blessed with a son named Isaac, and previously he had been blessed with a son from his wife Hajar.

Even though Sarah was very old and no longer able to bear children, the desire to have a son was always her longing, especially after hearing that Ismail had grown up and was always visited by her husband Ibrahim, to the place where he was raised in Mecca, which was very far from Palestine. Jealousy arose in her heart towards Hajar, her former maid, especially after she was married to Ibrahim with her permission. Added to Sarah's thoughts was why her maid was blessed by Allah SWT with a son, while she herself had not yet been blessed. This jealousy grew stronger over time. In such a situation, angels came to the two elderly spouses, conveying Allah's command to announce the good news that they would be blessed by Allah with a son named Isaac, a son who would be appointed as a prophet and messenger in the future.

This news was received by Ibrahim, especially Sarah, with wonder and disbelief, but full of hope. She almost did not believe the news because she was too old to conceive and give birth to a child. According to custom, a woman her age could not possibly give birth to a child. Nevertheless, she also had hope because the news came from the One God, conveyed by His messenger angels. She was convinced and believed that God is able to create what He wills; everything is easy for God.

The angel's announcement to Ibrahim and Sarah that they would have a son is described in Allah SWT's words:

"And his wife was standing, and she smiled. Then We gave her good tidings of Isaac and after Isaac, Jacob. She said, "Woe to me! Will I give birth while I am an old woman and this, my husband, is an old man? Indeed, this is a strange thing." They said, "Are you amazed at the decree of Allah? May the mercy of Allah and His blessings be upon you, people of the house. Indeed, He is Praiseworthy and Honorable." (Hud/11: 71-73)

And Allah SWT's words:

"(The angels) said, "Fear not. Indeed, we give you good tidings of a learned boy (Isaac)." He said, "Have you given me good tidings although old age has overtaken me? Then of what [wonder] do you give good tidings?" They said, "We have given you good tidings in truth, so do not be of those who despair." He said, "And who despairs of the mercy of his Lord except for those astray?" (al-Hijr/15: 53-56)

Ibrahim offered praise and gratitude to Allah, the Most Generous, for another of His blessings, namely granting his prayers, such as making the land of Mecca and its surroundings a sacred land, making him and some of his descendants righteous people, and even appointing his two sons, Ismail and Isaac, as prophets and messengers.

What Ibrahim (peace be upon him) felt when offering praise and gratitude to God is understandable, how happy he and his family were after striving hard, experiencing very difficult trials, facing obstacles and hindrances from his father and his people, then when his and his wife's age was increasing, he saw all the results of his efforts, almost everything he had asked of God in the past was granted. Even his aspiration to have offspring, which he initially felt would not be possible, then by the will of God, the Most Generous, was finally granted, so that his second son, Isaac, was born.
text.40:
In this verse, the expression of gratitude from Ibrahim to Allah for all His blessings is further depicted. He became increasingly submissive and obedient to Allah, and prayed that Allah would make his descendants always perform salat, never neglecting it in the slightest, perfecting its pillars and conditions, and also perfecting the performance of its sunnahs with full submission and humility.

Ibrahim a.s. prayed that his descendants would always perform salat, because salat is the differentiator between a believer (mukmin) and a disbeliever (kafir) and is the core of the worship that Allah has commanded. For a person who always performs salat, it will be easy for him to perform other acts of worship and righteous deeds. Salat can purify the soul and body because salat can prevent humans from indecent and evil deeds, as Allah swt says:

"And establish prayer. Indeed, prayer prohibits immorality and wrongdoing, and the remembrance of Allah is greater. And Allah knows that which you do." (al-Ankabut/29: 45)

Ibrahim a.s. pleaded to Allah swt to accept his acts of worship. This desire to worship God was given priority over the desire to follow his father's wishes, as Allah swt says:

"And I will leave you and those you invoke other than Allah and will invoke my Lord. I expect that I will not be in invocation to my Lord unhappy." (Maryam/19: 48)

What is meant by prayer (doa) in this verse is worship (ibadah). The Messenger of Allah (Rasulullah saw) stated that prayer is worship. Then he recited the word of Allah swt:

"Indeed, those who are near your Lord are not prevented by pride from His worship, and they exalt Him, and to Him they prostrate." (al-Araf/7: 206)
text.41:
Ibrahim, peace be upon him, prayed that Allah would forgive all his sins, the sins of his parents, and the sins of those who believe on the Day when Allah gathers them to be reckoned for all the deeds and actions they performed during their lives in the world.

It is narrated from al-Hasan that Ibrahim's mother was a believer in Allah, while his father was a disbeliever. He sought forgiveness for his father because he had promised to seek forgiveness for him. However, when it became clear that his father remained in his disbelief and became an enemy of Allah, he disavowed him, as mentioned in His word:

"And the request of forgiveness of Ibrahim for his father was only because of a promise he had made to him. But when it became clear to him that he was an enemy to Allah, he disavowed him. Indeed was Ibrahim tenderhearted and forbearing." (at-Taubah/9: 114)
text.42:
It is mentioned in history that the polytheists of Mecca always hindered and opposed the Prophet Muhammad and his companions in carrying out the da'wah (propagation of Islam) as God had commanded them. Day by day, these obstacles and hindrances increased, even to the point of persecution and boycotts. Many of the companions were persecuted. They refused to engage in trade, brotherhood, and mutual assistance with the Muslims. The torture and persecution were so severe that the Prophet's companions almost despaired. Meanwhile, the polytheists seemed to be emboldened by Allah, being given power and wealth. Their actions became increasingly reckless.

In such a situation, Allah warned the Prophet Muhammad saw with a verse stating, "O Muhammad, do not think that Allah swt is negligent and does not pay attention to the actions and deeds of the unjust polytheists of Mecca. Their actions and deeds are actions and deeds that oppress themselves. Allah will surely record all their deeds. Nothing will escape His record. All their actions and deeds will be given a fitting reward. Allah will put them into a blazing fire in the hereafter."

With the revelation of this verse, the hearts of the Prophet and his companions became calm. Their fighting spirit increased. They intensified their efforts to develop the religion of Allah. The heavier the pressure and persecution inflicted by the polytheists, the more they increased their efforts to spread Islam, because they believed that Allah would surely fulfill His promise.

This verse is addressed to the Prophet Muhammad saw, but what is meant is the entire ummah (community) of the Prophet Muhammad, including his ummah who live in the present time. Therefore, Muslims do not need to be influenced by the lives of the unjust who are full of luxury and pleasure, as if they are a people favored by Allah. All of this is only a trial from God and is temporary, until the appointed time, which is a day full of chaos and misery, on a day when human eyes will stare in fear of the retribution that Allah will give.
text.43:
In this verse, Allah swt explains the state of the wrongdoers during their life in the world, which is their state when resurrected from the graves, then heading towards the Gathering Place (Padang Mahsyar), they come rushing to fulfill the call of the caller who calls them with full humiliation. Their condition is like people who are about to undergo a hanging. They walk forward without turning to the right or left, their eyelids do not move and their eyes do not blink even a little. Their hearts at that time are empty and hollow, not thinking about anything except the fear of facing the terrible torment that will soon befall them.

In another verse, Allah swt describes the state of the disbelievers who are resurrected from the graves, namely:

So turn away (O Muhammad) from them. The Day the caller will call (them) to a terrible thing. With humbled eyes, they will emerge from the graves as if they were scattered locusts, hastening towards the caller. The disbelievers will say, "This is a difficult Day." (al-Qamar/54: 6-8)

And the word of Allah swt:

The Day they will emerge from the graves quickly as if they were rushing to (their idols) set up for worship. Their eyes lowered, overwhelmed by humiliation. That is the Day which they were promised. (al-Maarij/70: 43-44)
text.44:
In this verse, Allah swt commands to give a warning to the wrongdoers and the polytheists of Mecca, namely about the complaints and groans that come out of their mouths when the torment befalls them in the afterlife while pleading, "O our Lord, give us another chance, even for a moment, to obey Your call and follow the teachings of Your messenger by returning us to the world. If that opportunity is truly given to us, we will surely follow Your commands and stop Your prohibitions, we will truly purify our obedience to You alone, we will not associate partners with You again, O our Lord."

Their request is answered by Allah swt with His word:

And they swore by Allah their strongest oaths, "Allah will not resurrect one who dies." No, but it is a true promise [binding] upon Him, but most of the people do not know. (an-Nahl/16: 38)

According to a narration by al-Baihaqi from Muhammad bin Kaab Al-Quradhi, he said, "The inhabitants of hell pray to Allah five times. Four times Allah answers, and the fifth time Allah answers with an order that they no longer speak and that they remain confined in hell."

These prayers are mentioned in Allah's word as follows:

They will say, "Our Lord, You made us lifeless twice and gave us life twice, and we have confessed our sins. So is there to any way to get out?" (Gafir/40: 11)

This request is answered by Allah swt with His word:

That is because, when Allah alone was invoked, you disbelieved; but when partners were associated with Him, you believed. So the judgement is with Allah, the Most High, the Grand. (Gafir/40:12)

The second prayer of the inhabitants of hell is as Allah swt says:

And if you could but see when the criminals are hanging their heads before their Lord, [saying], "Our Lord, we have seen and heard, so return us [to the world]; we will work righteousness. Indeed, we are [now] certain." (As-Sajdah/32:12)

This request of theirs is answered by Allah swt in His word:

Then taste [the penalty] for your having forgotten the meeting of this Day of yours. Indeed, We have [accordingly] forgotten you. And taste the punishment of eternity for what you used to do. (as-Sajdah/32: 14)

The third prayer of the inhabitants of hell is as mentioned in Allah swt's word:

...then the wrongdoers will say, "Our Lord, delay us for a short term so we may answer Your call and follow the messengers..." (Ibrahim/14: 44)

This request of theirs is answered by Allah swt in His word:

[It will be said], "Had you not sworn before that there would be for you no cessation? (Ibrahim/14: 44)

The fourth prayer of the inhabitants of hell is as Allah swt says:

And they will cry out therein, "Our Lord, remove us; we will do righteousness - other than what we were doing!" (Fathir/35: 37)

Allah swt answers their request in His word:

But did We not give you lives long enough so that whoever would remember could remember therein, and the warner had come to you? So taste [the punishment], for there is not for the wrongdoers any helper. (Fathir/35: 37)

And the inhabitants of hell pray as mentioned in His word:

Our Lord, remove us from it, and if we were to return [to evil], we would indeed be wrongdoers." (al-Muminun/23: 107)

Finally, Allah swt answers firmly:

He will say, "Remain despised therein and do not speak to Me. (al-Muminun/23: 108)

After Allah swt's fifth answer, the mouths of the inhabitants of hell are silenced, there are no more prayers, other than the screams that come out of their mouths, because of the extreme severity of the hellfire torment that befalls them.
text.45: This verse reminds the Messenger of Allah (saw) and the believers that those who are unjust once lived in the lands of people who had wronged themselves and caused destruction on earth, as the people of 'Ad and Thamud had done. The punishment that Allah inflicted upon them is clear, and its traces are found in those lands based on the stories mentioned in the Al-Quran. Likewise, Allah (swt) has given parables to the Muslims about the consequences that the unjust will experience in this world and the hereafter. If the Muslims were to commit actions and deeds like those committed by the unjust, they would surely be afflicted with punishment as well, like the punishment that was inflicted upon the unjust of the past. Therefore, the Muslims should take lessons from the stories and events of those who came before.
text.46:
Allah SWT explains in this verse that the disbelievers of Mecca had devised evil plans to thwart the struggle of the Muslims. However, they did not realize that every evil plan of theirs was certainly known to Allah, nothing was hidden from Allah in the slightest. Allah thwarted every effort of theirs, so that their ideals and goals would not be achieved. In fact, their efforts were so great that if the plan were used to destroy a very sturdy mountain, it would be accomplished. But all their plans, no matter how great, could not defeat Allah's miracles, could not erase His verses, and could not hinder the development of Islam on earth.

This verse hints at the victory of the Muslims and the destruction of the polytheists of Mecca in the near future. This verse also applies to Muslims today, as long as they increase their strength and efforts, and are always patient and steadfast in facing the various sufferings and trials inflicted by the evil plans of the disbelievers.
text.47:
This verse explains that Allah SWT will not break His promise, no matter how great the evil plans of the disbelievers are. Do not think that Allah will violate the promise He has made with His messengers. That promise is: Allah will surely help His messengers and the believers with them, so that they achieve victory. Likewise, Allah will not break His promise to punish the disbelievers in the Hereafter, as mentioned in His previous word:

"Indeed, We are only deferring them for a Day when eyes will stare [in horror]." (Ibrahim/14: 42)

At the end of this verse, Allah SWT affirms that He is All-Powerful and Severe in punishment. No one can escape His demands. He will surely retaliate and punish those who hinder His messengers.
text.48:
This verse explains that the time of recompense and the execution of punishment is on the Day when the earth will be replaced with another earth, when Allah destroys the heavens and everything in them and replaces them with other heavens. At that time, the earth, moon, and all the stars will collide, shattering into dust and scattering like clouds, then another earth and heavens will come into being.

Ibn Abbas said, "The other earth is none other than the earth that has changed its characteristics from the earth that exists now, such as its mountains having moved, its water no longer flowing, and its seas having died, neither turbulent nor calm."

From the verse and the narration of Ibn Abbas above, it can be understood that later on the Day of Judgment, the entire universe will be utterly destroyed. Each part will collide with the other, shattering and scattering in space for some time, then forming something like the shape of the earth and heavens, but it will not be the earth and heavens that exist now.

The state of mankind at that time is explained by the Messenger of Allah (saw) in this hadith:

From Aishah, she said, "I was the first person to ask the Messenger of Allah (saw) about this verse." Aishah said, "I asked, 'Where will people be at that time, O Messenger of Allah?'" The Messenger of Allah (saw) replied, "On the *shirath* (straight path)." (Narrated by Muslim)
text.49:
These verses explain the state of humans when resurrected from their graves after the destruction of the world. They rise from their graves towards and stop before Allah the Almighty to receive the judgment of punishment. On that day, there are no close friends who can help and assist, no children and family who can comfort the heart from the feeling of anxiety being felt, and no one can take refuge in anyone except in the Almighty Lord.

After Allah SWT describes His power and might on that day, He describes the weakness and helplessness of the sinners at that time by explaining their state while being punished, namely:

1. The sinners at that time are bound together, from their hands to their feet, together with their idols when they were alive in the world. This state shows the similarity of their attitudes and actions when they were alive in the world. Because they are equally disbelieving in Allah, it is fitting that they equally receive punishment, as explained in His word:

So they (the idols) will be thrown into Hell, together with the deviators, and the soldiers of Iblis, all of them. (ash-Shuara/26: 94-95)

2. They wear clothes made of asphalt. What is meant by this verse is not clothing in the true sense, but the entire bodies of the sinners at that time are covered in hot asphalt. Thus, four kinds of torment being suffered by the disbelievers can be described, namely hot asphalt that burns and scorches the body, raging fire in the body, a terrifying black color, and the smell of rotting flesh.

3. Their faces are licked by fire. In line with this verse, the word of Allah SWT:

The Day they are dragged into the Fire on their faces, (it will be said), "Taste the touch of Hell." (al-Qamar/54: 48)
text.50:
These verses explain the state of humans when resurrected from their graves after the destruction of the world. They rise from the graves towards and stop before Allah the Almighty to receive the judgment of punishment. On that day, there are no close friends who can help and assist, no children and family who can comfort the heart from the feeling of anxiety that is being felt, and no one can take refuge in anyone except in the Almighty Lord.

After Allah SWT describes His power and might on that day, He describes the weakness and helplessness of the sinners at that time by explaining their state while being punished, namely:

1. The sinners at that time are bound together, from their hands to their feet, together with their idols when they were alive in the world. This state shows the similarity of their attitudes and actions when they were alive in the world. Because they are equally disbelieving in Allah, it is fitting that they receive the same punishment, as explained in His word:

So they (the idols) will be thrown into Hell, together with the deviators, and the soldiers of Iblis, all of them. (ash-Syuara/26: 94-95)

2. They wear clothes made of asphalt. What is meant by this verse is not clothing in the true sense, but the entire bodies of the sinners at that time are covered in hot asphalt. Thus, four kinds of torment being suffered by the disbelievers can be described: hot asphalt that burns and scorches the body, raging fire in the body, a terrifying black color, and the smell of rotting flesh.

3. Their faces are licked by fire. In line with this verse, the word of Allah SWT:

The Day they are dragged into the Fire on their faces, (it will be said), "Taste the touch of Hell." (al-Qamar/54: 48)
text.51: Allah SWT does this on the Day of Judgment to give recompense to humans for what they did during their lives in the world. They receive rewards or the punishment of hell according to the deeds they have done. On that day, Allah SWT swiftly reckons the accounts of His servants.
text.52:
At the conclusion of this surah, Allah swt explains that this noble Al-Quran contains teachings, warnings, and frightening news conveyed by His Messenger to mankind, because some of its verses explain the consequences that sinners will experience in the afterlife. Those who are willing to learn from its verses will live happily in this world, and in the hereafter will obtain pleasure and enjoyment in Paradise as a reward for the good deeds they have done.

This is explained by the word of Allah swt:

Say, "Allah is sufficient as a witness between me and you. And this Qur'an has been revealed to me that I may warn you thereby and whomever it reaches." (al-Anam/6: 19)

And the word of Allah swt:

Alif, Lam, Ra. [This is] a Book which We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], that you might bring mankind out of darknesses into the light by permission of their Lord - to the path of the Exalted in Might, the Praiseworthy. (Ibrahim/14: 1)

Likewise, so that mankind may use the proofs and arguments contained in the Al-Quran as a basis for establishing and believing that there is no God worthy of worship other than the One God. He who subjugated the sun, moon, stars, night, day, sea, and air for mankind and sent down rain from the sky so that the rainwater would grow various kinds of plants that are beneficial for human life and livelihood. In the sea, there are various kinds of God's blessings, such as fish, pearls, minerals, and so on, which are lawful sustenance for mankind. It's just that many people are unwilling to acknowledge the existence of Allah's diverse blessings.
